oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Sweethearts of the Rodeo Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Sweethearts of the Rodeo (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Sweethearts of the Rodeo; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Janis Oliver discusses her and Kristine Arnold's first experiences singing together in Manhattan Beach, California -- (00:44) Oliver recalls her first memory; Arnold says her first memory was of a party for United Nations Day -- (01:59) Biff Collie inquires and Arnold states that Pearl Hinforth (unconfirmed) was her and Oliver's biggest influence; Oliver reflects on Hinforth's artistic influences -- (03:55) Arnold reveals that, while in church, "Trust and Obey" was the first song she and Oliver ever performed -- (05:14) Collie and the Sweethearts of the Rodeo discuss the girls' love of performing from a young age -- (05:57) Oliver discusses the various attempts the girls had, at a young age, to shape their performing careers; Arnold discusses her and Oliver's age difference affecting their relationship -- (08:59) Collie has Oliver and Arnold recall their reactions to each other bringing home dates -- (09:57) Collie and the Sweethearts of the Rodeo reflect on how working at the Pizza Palace led to Emmylou Harris and others coming to watch them perform -- (11:16) Arnold reveals her and Oliver's first studio experience came from being background vocalists in high school; Oliver reveals some of her and Arnold's first experiences came from working with Cliffie Stone -- (13:34) Collie and the Sweethearts of the Rodeo discuss how winning the Wrangler Country Showdown gained them popularity -- (14:56) Oliver discusses how she met her husband, Vince Gill -- (16:00) Arnold discusses the difficulty of starting a career in Nashville, and how if she and Oliver didn't have the connections they did it would have been a lot more difficult -- (18:00) Arnold suggests aspiring artists should do talent shows -- (18:41) Collie and the Sweethearts of the Rodeo discuss how they had signed with CBS while touring with Willie Nelson -- (19:31) Oliver and Arnold discuss their personal lives -- (20:48) Arnold and Oliver attribute their success to Hinforth and their ballet instructor -- (22:04) Collie has Arnold and Oliver recall the Wrangler Country Showdown -- (23:44) Oliver recalls the first song she ever wrote ("Gotta Get Away") was written for the Wrangler Country Showdown -- (24:22) Oliver and Arnold recall "Wolverton Mountain" by Claude King was the first record they ever owned -- (25:09) "Since I Found you" is revealed to be the first top-ten record the Sweethearts of the Rodeo created, and it is revealed that they have yet to reach number one -- (25:26) Arnold and Oliver believe that Hank Williams Sr. is the most influential country artist -- (26:10) Arnold and Oliver reflect on their favorite time to think and who they believe should be in the Country Music Hall of Fame® and Museum
